overview: This subject aims to provide students with a thorough understanding of the tree selection and tree identification principles. Students should be able to recognise trees commonly used in landscape horticulture and correctly write their botanical, common and family names and describe tree form and tolerances. They should be able to write plant names in accordance with the ICN (International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi and plants) and the ICNCP (International Code of Nomenclature for Cultivated Plants). The subject will be delivered through attendance at a six day intensive workshop.
ilo: Apply family characteristics to identify a wide range of trees;
Analyse the tolerances and cultural conditions of a wide range of trees, to assist in tree selection and establishment;
Discuss the use trees in the landscape; and
Analyse different sites for tree selection and establishment.
generic_skills: Technical and discipline areas; for example through their study of tree families;
Investigation and analysis; for example through their analysis of sites for tree selection and establishment;
Critical thinking and problem solving; for example through their selection of trees for difficult urban sites; and
Time and organisational management; with the successful scheduling of assessment.

Inherent requirements (core participatio.content: Further details on how to seek academic adjustments can be found on the Student Equity and Disability Support website:http://services.unimelb.edu.au/student-equity/home

assessment.brief: One short test during the intensive delivery
One test at the end of the intensive delivery
Post-intensive written assignment due 3 weeks after the intensive delivery
assessment.timing: 3 Weeks after the end of teaching

assessment.brief: Post-intensive written assignment due 7 weeks after the intensive delivery
assessment.timing: 7 Weeks after the end of teaching

date_times.contact_hours: 42 hours: 5 x 3 hrs lecture, 5 x 2 hrs practical, 3 x 3 hrs tutorial, 2 x 2 hrs tutorial and 1 x 4 hrs tutorial during the 6 day intensive.
